article.description:
Utah Jazz got scoring and leadership
down the stretch from John Stockton and Karl Malone.
article.headline: Utah outscores Mavericks 18-1 down the stretch

images.name: Nash_Steve 121001 horiz top
images.caption: Steve Nash scored 25 points, but couldn't lead the Mavs past Utah and John Crotty, left.

article.linkText: Utah uses old and new to mount comeback against Dallas
article.story:
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- The Utah Jazz got scoring and leadership down the stretch from John Stockton and Karl Malone. They got great defense, too, from Russian rookie Andrei Kirilenko, and the mix of new and old this season seems to be taking hold at last. Malone scored 30 points and had 10 rebounds while Stockton had 21 points and 12 assists as the Jazz rallied in the fourth quarter to beat the Dallas Mavericks 107-98 Monday night. It was Utah's fourth consecutive victory, coming after a frustrating opening where Utah got off to its worst start in 19 years. "We're learning," Stockton said. "We have some young guys and some very old guys and the mix takes some time to learn. We're getting a little bit better and at least it's something we can build off of." It was a rematch of the first-round playoff series of last year, but this time the Jazz came from behind to win. Last spring, the visiting Mavericks outscored Utah 21-12 in the fourth quarter to win the decisive fifth game. Afterward, neither team wanted to make comparisons. "You play so many games. There are so many combinations, so many permutations," said Dallas guard Steve Nash. "I don't know if we can make any correlations to last year's game." Donyell Marshall scored 17, including seven in the final 3 minutes and Malone had nine in the last 4½ minutes. Kirilenko added a huge block of a shot by Juwan Howard as Utah outscored Dallas 18-1 over the last 4:39. "That was a nice block," Stockton said. "It was a very timely one and those are some of the special things that guy can do. It's nice to have him out there doing them." The Mavericks went ahead 97-89 with 4:53 to go when Eduardo Najera took a feed from Nash for a dunk that capped a 7-2 run. But that was the last Dallas field goal. Dirk Nowitzki, back in the starting lineup after missing the defeat Saturday against Washington, scored 27 points and had 10 rebounds to lead the Mavericks while Nash scored 25. Howard and Najera scored 12 each. Kirilenko had 16 points and six steals for Utah. "Every guy on the floor had a hand in something down the stretch, and that's what we need," Malone said. "Not just me, not just Stock, Andrei, Donyell, (John) Crotty. Everybody out there did something positive." After Utah's struggles early in the season, the victory was a good start to a tough week. Still ahead are home games against Minnesota and Portland, and a road trip to San Antonio. The Mavericks lost their third in a row and fell to 0-8 in games in which they trailed entering the fourth quarter. "It's tough that we didn't come up with a win, but we've got to get over this one, go home, get some sleep and be ready for tomorrow," Nash said. Dallas seized the momentum early in the fourth behind Najera's hustle and Nowitzki's shooting. Throw in 3-pointers by Nash and Tim Hardaway, and the Mavericks seemed to have everything under control. "Down the stretch, they made big shots and we didn't," Nowitzki said. "We had good looks but we didn't execute any more like we did for three quarters." Game notes
With a pair of free throws in the first quarter, Malone passed Wilt Chamberlain (11,862) for most attempts in NBA history. In 17 seasons, the Mailman has 11,877. ... Early in the second half, Stockton made the 800th 3-pointer of his 18-year career. ... Dallas coach Don Nelson is nine victories from becoming the third coach in league history, behind Lenny Wilkins (1,237) and Pat Riley (1,051) to reach 1,000 victories. ... Jazz coach Jerry Sloan got his 700th victory with Utah. He is seven from No. 800 overall. ... Greg Ostertag of the Jazz didn't play. ... Utah shot 42 free throws, compared to 24 by Dallas.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
